column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: Removing barriers and creating career pathways for team members with disabilities to join, grow and thrive at Coles remains a key focus. Highlights from this year included providing six team members with lived experience of disability and international and local opportunities to participate in tailored leadership development programs, including the Valuable500Ã¢ÂÂs Generation Valuable program, Disability Leadership InstituteÃ¢ÂÂs Future Shapers program and The Observership program for aspiring board members.

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: Removing barriers and creating career pathways for team members with disabilities to join, grow and thrive at Coles remains a key focus. Highlights from this year included participating in the Directing Change program, which pairs a Coles leader with an external person with a disability who is building their governance knowledge to contribute to Boards.

column6: Ratio of basic salary and remuneration of women to men
Incidents of discrimination and corrective actions taken
column7: We received a few allegations of discrimination by customers against Coles team members. No allegations were substantiated. We also received a small number of discrimination claims by team members against other team members, resulting in disciplinary action.

column4: Freedom of Association and Collective Bargaining
column6: Operations and suppliers in which the right to freedom of association and collective bargaining may be at risk
column7: Non-compliance with critical laws and regulations could expose Coles to loss of licence to operate, substantial financial penalties, reputational damage, a deterioration in relationships with regulators, class action or other litigation and additional regulatory changes that may adversely impact the execution of our strategy and result in increased cost to operate. Where Coles is a party to litigation, it can involve reputational damage, financial costs, and high investment of Company resources and time.

column6: Operations and suppliers at significant risk for incidents of child labor
column13: If child labour is identified, our policy requires that the supplier immediately remove the child labourer from the workplace and give them a viable alternative activity and location that is safe and in the best interests of the child. The child must be given access to schooling, paid an ongoing wage and benefits, and guaranteed a job at the workplace upon reaching the appropriate age.
column20: Child Labour, Supplier, Vaiable Alternative Activity

column6: Operations and suppliers ar significant risk for incidents of forced or compulsory labor
column13: Suppliers are expected to comply with the legal requirements of the countries where they operate, in addition to ColesÃ¢ÂÂ Ethical Sourcing Policy elements. All Australian suppliers must comply with all Australian laws and regulations regarding labour, wages and benefits, health, safety (including psychosocial safety), anti-discrimination, sex-based misconduct and the environment.
column20: Coles' Ethical Sourcing Policy, Safety, Supplier

column6: Operations and suppliers ar significant risk for incidents of forced or compulsory labor
column13: Suppose a supplierÃ¢ÂÂs worker pays a recruitment fee or deposit for their employment or contract for services other than, or in addition to, the direct costs of travel, visas and additional legitimate expenses. In that case, Coles will work with the supplier on appropriate remediation. Payslips and financial records must be made available for auditor review, verifying that the worker is no longer in debt. Key employment terms and conditions must be reissued to all workers in their language. Any worker found to have entered an employment or contract for services arrangement against their free will must be immediately freed, with no notice period required.
column20: Recruitment Fee or Deposits, Contact for Services, Direct Cost and other Legitimate Cost

column6: Operations and suppliers ar significant risk for incidents of forced or compulsory labor
column13: Continued expansion of ColesÃ¢ÂÂ Ethical Sourcing program into the supply of rubber gloves used in stores, refrigeration units, employee laptops and provision of services such as offshore warehousing and livestock transport. Enhanced requirements for additional high-risk raw materials in the renewable energy sector. Creation and trial of an audit methodology designed explicitly for assessing labour-based service providers.

column6: Operations and suppliers ar significant risk for incidents of forced or compulsory labor

Coles implemented a supplier capacity-building program for selected strategic suppliers to identify and improve their ethical sourcing and human rights practices.

Coles established a cross-functional internal working group that engages with our suppliers to develop further our approach to critical issues, including animal welfare, feed ingredients and impacts on the marine environment.

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: RSPO membership means that within the food and drink supply chain for Coles Own Brand products sold in Coles Supermarkets, Coles requires suppliers using palm oil to Obtain RSPO Supply Chain Certification for its supply chain or Be able to demonstrate RSPO Certification for each palm oil ingredient that is incorporated into the Coles Own Brand product.
column20: Coles Own Brand, Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil, Retailers Palm Oil Group

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: In FY23, more than 96% of fresh produce, by volume, was sourced from suppliers all over Australia. 100% of Coles Own Brand fresh pork, chicken, turkey, duck, beef, lamb, milk and eggs were Australian-grown. There are some situations where fresh produce cannot be sourced from Australia, and we will continue to work closely with our growers to try and find solutions to supply challenges. We comply with country-of-origin labelling requirements, making it easier for customers to identify where a product is from.
column20: Fresh Produce, Coles Own Brand Fresh Pork, Country-of-origin Labelling Requirements

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Since 2012, we have supported The Weekly Times Coles Farmer of the Year Awards, which aims to create a platform for recognition of the exceptional work of farmers across Australia. In FY23, winners were family-run businesses demonstrating a solid commitment to innovation and sustainability, enhancing AustraliaÃ¢ÂÂs reputation as a food production and agribusiness leader.
column20: The Weekly Times, Coles Farmer of the Year Awards, Family-Run Businesses

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Coles continued to offer farmers the option of either one, two or three-year agreements, providing them with pricing transparency and income certainty. Simultaneously, this has supported Coles in securing an ongoing supply of fresh milk for customers.
column20: Two or three-year agreements, pricing transparency, income certainty

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Through the Coles Sustainable Dairy Development Group (CSDDG), we invested in sustainability projects in consultation with dairy farmers. These included energy assessments and workshops, an on-farm field day to share findings from a two-year trial to evaluate heat stress in cows and VAT monitors to optimise milk quality and milk collection efficiencies.
column20: Coles Sustainable Dairy Development Group (CSDDG), Sustainable Projects, Dairy Farmers
